NewsÂ ğŸ“°

  • Yesterday, in aÂ press release, theÂ UCIÂ reported that WWT ridersâ€™ salaries and budgets had increased in 2021. The press release showed the results of an audit by external firm EY Lausanne which found that the average salary for a WWT rider had increased by 25% between 2020 and 2021. This is great news for WWT riders who make up 160 riders, but not so great for the 771 riders on Continental teams. The press release failed to give credit to the initiative taken by WWT teams includingÂ BikeExchangeÂ andÂ Trek-SegafredoÂ to increase riders salaries beyond the minimum stipulated by the UCI. WWT riders still earn on average 44.21% less than their male ProTeam counterparts. With no mention of the situation for Continental riders, the press release also failed to address the ever-widening gap between the upper echelons of the womenâ€™s peloton and the rest of the bunch, whichÂ The Cyclistsâ€™ Alliance 2020 Rider SurveyÂ showed was growing. In short, thereâ€™s still work to do!
  • Cycling AustraliaÂ have announced their Olympic road squad forÂ Tokyo.Â Grace Brown,Â Sarah Gigante,Â Tiffany Cromwell,Â andÂ Alexandra ManlyÂ will be heading to the Games for the first time to joinÂ Amanda SprattÂ for her third Olympics. Brown and Gigante will also race the ITT.
  • On the subject of Australian riders,Â Lucy KennedyÂ ofÂ BikeExchangeposted an update on Twitter on her condition after her crash in LiÃ©ge-Bastogne-LiÃ©ge. She is back on the trainer after having surgery on complicated fractures in her hand and clavicle and added that a fractured eye socket is healing on its own.
  • And in further Aussie news,Â FDJ Nouvelle Aquitaine FuturoscoperiderÂ Lauren KitchenÂ announced via InstagramÂ that she will be retiring from the sport as of today. All the best for the future, Lauren.Â 
  • After her second place finish inÂ NovÃ© MÄ›stoÂ on Sunday,Â Haley Battenhas qualified from the US MTB team for theÂ Tokyo Olympic GamesÂ alongsideÂ Kate Courtney.
  • The Cyclistsâ€™ AllianceÂ have announced a new Mentorship Programme aimed at assisting riders before, during, and after their career. The union have joined forces withÂ Cannondale,Â Liv Cycling,Â Specialized,Â SRAMÂ andÂ TrekÂ to offer internships to retiring riders â€œwith the ultimate goal of creating long-term change beyond the bike.â€ Read more on TCAâ€™sÂ website.Â 
  • Details of the newÂ UCI Track Champions LeagueÂ have been revealed. The series â€” which will be organised by Flanders Classics â€” will kick off in November and be raced across Saturday evenings in November and December. More detailsÂ here.
  • Coffee brand,Â Segafredo,Â have extended their title sponsorship with both the menâ€™s and womenâ€™sÂ Trek-SegafredoÂ teamsÂ for a further two years.
  • The 2021 editions of the WWTÂ PostnordÂ VÃ¥rgÃ¥rdaÂ WestSwedenÂ TTT and road race have both been cancelled. Organisers announced the cancellation â€” now for the second year in a row â€”Â due to Coronavirus concerns but said they are focusing on the 2022 event.Â 
  • Some very sad news as US Masters championÂ Gwen InglisÂ was hit and killed by a suspected drunk driver last Sunday. Tributes have been paid to Inglis, who was 46 and won her national title in 2019, and aride was held in her memory.Â 
  • The organisers of theÂ UCI Track Cycling Nations CupÂ due to take place inÂ Cali, ColombiaÂ between 3rd and 6th June have requested to postpone the event as a result of the ongoing tensions in the country. The organisers and the UCI are looking for alternative dates.

Results ğŸ†

  • Anna van der BreggenÂ came back to racing and went straight back to winning at theÂ Gran Premio Ciudad de EibarÂ 1.1 on Sunday. In yet another wet and wild race that included multiple attacks â€” as well as a few crashes â€” the World Champion went solo and nobody else could follow. The rest of the field trickled in, withÂ Annemiek van Vleutencame in solo for second at 15 seconds andÂ Elisa Longo BorghiniÂ â€” also aloneâ€” 42 seconds back to take third. You can watch a replay of the YouTube livestreamÂ here. The action starts at 44 minutes in after some footage of old guns (ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸) although maybe youâ€™re in to that sort of thing too.Â 
  • Two days later the heavens opened again andÂ van der BreggenÂ took her second win atÂ Durango â€“ Durango Emakumeen Saria 1.1. If you didnâ€™t see the race then I recommend youÂ watch it back, at least for the final 20km whereinÂ Cecilie Uttrup LudwigÂ attacks solo and, after getting caught, makes an almighty effort to bridge up to van Vleuten and van der Breggen at the front to hang on for third.Â 
  • Over inÂ NovÃ© MÄ›stoÂ at theÂ UCI MTB XCOÂ world cup it was a dominantÂ Loana LecomteÂ who took her second World Cup win in as many weeks on Sunday.Â Haley Batten, who won the short track race on Friday, took second place after overtakingÂ Rebecca McConnellÂ on the final lap. Lecomte now leads the overall competition by 145Â points ahead of Batten.Â 
  • Thursday marked the first stage ofÂ Vuelta a Burgos FÃ©minas 2.WWTwon byÂ Grace BrownÂ (Team BikeExchange) after the Australian rider took off on the final climb bringingÂ Elise ChabbeyÂ (Canyon//SRAM) with her.Â Niamh Fisher BlackÂ ofÂ SD WorxÂ bridged and the trio held on until the line with Chabbey out-sprinting Fisher Black to take second. Brown took the GC lead on the same time as Fisher Black and Chabbey with the rest of the favourites 5 seconds back. Race reportÂ here. Stage 1 highlights videoÂ here.Stage two was won solo byÂ Anastasiia ChursinaÂ ofÂ Ale BTC LjubljanaÂ whileÂ Alice BarnesÂ ofÂ Canyon//SRAMÂ won the bunch sprint for second ahead ofÂ Amalie DideriksenÂ ofÂ Trek-Segafredo.Â Elise ChabbeyÂ moved into the leaderâ€™s jersey on positioning withÂ Niamh Fisher BlackÂ second andÂ Grace BrownÂ third, the rest of the favourites remain at 5 seconds. Race reportÂ here.
